questions.question_text: Ann, a security analyst, wants to implement a secure exchange of email. Which of the following is the BEST option for Ann to implement?

discussion.content: Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is an encryption program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication. PGP is used for signing, encrypting, and decrypting texts, e-mails, files, directories, and whole disk partitions and to increase the security of e-mail communications.
if u cant SMIME it always PGP dat ish

comments.content: I like your style
I like ya cut g

discussion.content: Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is a method used to secure email communication. It can encrypt, decrypt, and digitally sign email. gibson page 450
pgp can be used for email encryption

questions.question_text:
After a security assessment was performed on the enterprise network, it was discovered that:
1. Configuration changes have been made by users without the consent of IT.
2. Network congestion has increased due to the use of social media.
3. Users are accessing file folders and network shares that are beyond the scope of their need to know.
Which of the following BEST describe the vulnerabilities that exist in this environment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I chose AD as well. My reasoning is below:

A) Clearly users haven't been trained not to use social media at work as network congestion has increased due to the use of social media.

D) Clearly users accounts are improperly configured as they are accessing file folders and network shares that are beyond the scope of their need to know.

comments.content: If Amy the Administrative Assistant can access invoices and financial statements from accounting .... then my business process is vulnerable
I wouldn't have said E as there's no indication that a business process is indeed vulnerable. I can see how you could infer that one is, but it isn't explicitly stated in the question.
I agree with this because trained users with least privilege would’ve curtailed this.

"Configuration changes have been made by users without the consent of IT"

They've been trained... They just don't care
If accounts had been configured properly then they wouldn't be able to make config changes.

discussion.content: I would have said DE
usually social media is blocked at organizations, hence, E may be the option instead of A

D. Users are configured as admin 
E. On boarding or permission approval process is faulty allowing user to have wrong role

A and D are the best answers but if i can choose more than two, E would absolutely be on that list. Being able to access files beyond the scope of their need to know sounds like a vulnerable business process to me.

Answer: D, E
Explanation:
Users can make configuration changes and they can access folders and shares beyond their job requirements, so their accounts are improperly configured.
Social media use is virtually unchecked, so there are vulnerable business practices.

Personnel use social media and personal email accounts in ways that
bring risk to the organization—Remind the employee of the policy and
inform them of how divulging too much information on social media can
help attackers.

I would say that the question did not mention the expantion of any one usiness process so one must assume that either the persone setting up the permisions messed up or training was not done. Again we all know that we can do all the training in the world and employees will do what they can get away with but with the information giving and not wanting to point figures training sounds good to me.
i agree. The users were certainly trained well enough to modify the network configuration!

questions.question_text: A security administrator wants to determine if a company's web servers have the latest operating system and application patches installed. Which of the following types of vulnerability scans should be conducted?

discussion.content: Passive scanners emphasize monitoring network activity, while active scanners are capable of simulating attacks and repairing weak spots. Credentialed scans, which make use of the admin account, do a more thorough check by looking for problems that cannot be seen from the network. On the other hand, non-credentialed scans provide a quick view of vulnerabilities by only looking at network services exposed by the host - does not provide many details on these missing patches. . We should fix the vulnerabilities found with a non-credentialed scan first, as this is what the hacker will see when they enter your network. An active non-credentialed scan is also known as an unauthenticated scan,

comments.content: Credentialed Scan
Thanks, that was really helpful.

discussion.content: … Security administrators often run credentialed scans with the privileges of an administrator account. This allows the scan to check security issues at a much deeper level than a non- credentialed scan. Additionally, because the credentialed scan has easier access to internal workings of systems, it results in a lower impact on the tested systems, along with more accurate test results and fewer false positives. … (Darril Gibson’s Get Certified Get Ahead p. 574)

Scan types
• Scanners are very powerful
• Use many different techniques 
to identify vulnerabilities
• Non-intrusive scans
• Gather information, don’t try to 
exploit a vulnerability
• Intrusive scans
• You’ll try out the vulnerability to see if it works
• Non-credentialed scans
• The scanner can’t login to the remote device
• Credentialed scan
• You’re a normal user, 
emulates an insider attack
Credentialed scan

questions.question_text: During a recent audit, several undocumented and unpatched devices were discovered on the internal network. Which of the following can be done to prevent similar occurrences?

discussion.content:
I don't think the major problem here is unpatched, but undocumented...
should be b for sure

comments.content: sorry i meant to unvote lol.. plz dont choose this in the exam cuz A is Correcttttt...

discussion.content: A. Not B (rogue system detection does not detect missing patches - only rogue systems). A vulnerability scan will detect new devices and patching problems as well.
....prevent similar occurrences? so A is the correct answer...

NOT A. "... on all company devices..." these are devices that you didn't know you had, so you can't deploy patches to them, you could detect them with a vuln subnet scan but by that time they are already on your network.

D. is the best answer, but it doesn't specifically mention they are connecting to wireless.

I believe it’s A. The question makes no mention about them being unauthorized devices just that they are undocumented and missing patches. This is likely the of an asset management issue so A would be the best option.
I don't understand why there is 30 comments on a basic question. It's A.
You can't assume something when you read the questions. Just because something isn't documented doesn't mean it is rouge. It could be sloppy documentation of assets.
You can't assume something when you read the questions. Just because something isn't documented doesn't mean it is rouge. It could be sloppy documentation of assets.

"several UNDOCUMENTED and UNPATCHED devices were discovered" " which of the following can be done to PREVENT"
B - does not PREVENT...only detects and alerts
I'm going with D

comments.content: Actually upon further research I believe A is the correct answer

discussion.content: A would comprise of B so it has to be A
If WAPs are network devices , then they can be configured to use NAC. Such as PacketFence NAC on top of FreeRadius and configure WAPs to use NAC. I will go with "D" tomorrow in exam.

comments.content:
Yes, 'A' is correct. Vulnerability scans can enumerate the devices on your network (so you'll be able to see rogue devices), as well as identify patch levels.

'B' won't provide patch information.
'C' has nothing to do with the question.
'D' only mentions wireless access, while most company networks are both wired and wireless.

discussion.content: A is correct
Guys, it's D. because with NAC you will prevent that from happening.

comments.content: The systems were not said to have been connected via wireless so the use of WAP makes the option a wrong one
What about the wired devices connect to a ethernet jack? Answer D only allows for devices that are wireless.

discussion.content: i Think the answer is "B" assuming the "undocumented" are also the "unpatched devices" and the "rogue system detection" will prevent rouge devices to be added to the network

rogue system detection
The process of identifying and removing any hosts that are not supposed to be on a
network.

I think the answer is D

If you truly want to stop unpatched devices from connecting to your network use NAC. This will make them update, provide virus protection, pass health checks. The question states to prevent this from happening anymore.
I won't be surprised if there are two options to chose from on the exam. Both are correct and both remediate the issues found

Rogue system detection should be implemented to avoid penetrating the wireless network by intruders or hackers and to protect from malicious attack.

DLP controls or software has to be installed to detect and monitor the sensitive data being lost in the network and to avoid data leakage or data loss

WAP is a protocol for the information being transmitted through the mobile network.

NAC is to ensure authenticating the system and to enforce network security.

To prevent undocumented and unpatched devices from the network "Run weekly vulnerability scans and remediate any missing patches on all company devices".

comments.content: The fact that it mentions a WAP is an issue, for me at least. Nowhere in the question does it state the network is wireless only. If the rogue machines are plugging into RJ45 ports, D does nothing.

discussion.content:
A - doesn’t address the devices being undocumented
B - doesn’t address the devices being unpatched
C - No related to the scenario
D - NAC will prevent unauthorised devices connecting to the network and requires all devices pass a health check before joining the network. (You’ll get redirected to a remedial network first to download patches).

Answer is definitely D - assuming it mentioning that it uses a WAP isn’t some sort of trap.

D – The problem is “undocumented devices” and “unpatched devices” found, and we need to PREVENT similar occurrences.
A scan will DETECT but not PREVENT. However a NAC (Network Access Control) with Health Checks will PREVENT computers that don't meet the health check conditions. Part of the health checks a device would need to pass would be that the device is registered in Active Directory or a similar network inventory. If not it would be flagged and rejected.

comments.content: Finally, some sense in these discussions. Thank you. Yes the answer is D.

MelvinJohn has two distinct personalities, one Melvin, another John. He always has more than one answer and appropriate explanations of those. 

I agree with this statement.

A. Not B (rogue system detection does not detect missing patches - only rogue systems). A vulnerability scan will detect new devices and patching problems as well.
___
I don't think D will completely address a problem, because we don't have a problem just with wireless devices, we can have wired rogue devices.

discussion.content:
I think this is a question where you have to select two answers.
A & B

comments.content: I did initially but on a second look, the systems were not said to have been connected via wireless so the use of WAP makes the option a wrong one

discussion.content: anyone else went w D?

comments.content:
I don’t think the question points at that. 

Undocumented systems exist
Unpatched systems also exist
Some might be in both situations (undocumented and unpatched)
Melvin is correct I believe.

discussion.content: I agreed with Melvin until I realized that the question appears to say that the unpatched devices ARE the undocumented ones. So the patch posture is likely already ok. The issue then, is the rogue unpatched devices. Tricky wording.
key "several undocumented devices" .. ANS B.. those are rogue systems

comments.content: Agreed. If the devices are undocumented, you have to assume they are rogue until proven otherwise.

discussion.content: That would be my second choice, but vulnerability scan can also detect undocumented (rogue) devices

choices.D: Configure the WAPs to use NAC and refuse connections that do not pass the health check
choices.A: Run weekly vulnerability scans and remediate any missing patches on all company devices
choices.B: Implement rogue system detection and configure automated alerts for new devices
choices.C: Install DLP controls and prevent the use of USB drives on devices

C. The captive portal requires users to acknowledge and agree to abide by an acceptable use policy (AUP). (Darril Gibson Sec+ Book)

questions.question_text: A company needs to implement a system that only lets a visitor use the company's network infrastructure if the visitor accepts the AUP. Which of the following should the company use?
